questions.text: Match the following:

options.label: A
options.text: A-Putamen; B- Globus Pallidus; C- Caudate Nucleus; D- Subthalamic Nucleus; E- Substantia Nigra; F- Thalamus

options.label: B
options.text: A- Caudate Nucleus; B- Putamen; C- Thalamus; D- Globus Pallidus; E- Subthalamic Nucleus; F- Substantia Nigra

options.label: C
options.text: A- Caudate Nucleus; B- Globus Pallidus; C- Substantia Nigra; D- Globus Pallidus; E- Thalamus; F- Subthalamic Nucleus

options.label: D
options.text: A- Caudate Nucleus; B- Putamen; C- Globus Pallidus; D- Thalamus; E- Subthalamic Nucleus; F- Substantia Nigra

questions.correct_answer: B. A- Caudate Nucleus; B- Putamen; C- Thalamus; D- Globus Pallidus; E- Subthalamic Nucleus; F- Substantia Nigra

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cerebellar circuitry is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Climbing fibres directly excite Purkinje cells by forming extensive synaptic connections.

options.label: B
options.text: Mossy fibres excite Purkinje cells through granule cells, creating a diffuse excitatory effect.

options.label: C
options.text: Purkinje cells send excitatory signals to deep cerebellar nuclei.

options.label: D
options.text: Stellate, basket, and Golgi cells serve as inhibitory interneurons in the cerebellar cortex.

questions.correct_answer: C. Purkinje cells send excitatory signals to deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: Which type of fibres enter the cerebellum via the middle cerebellar peduncle?
questions.explanation:
Afferent fibres

Tract

Enter Cerebellum Via

Target and Function

Climbing fibres

Olivo-cerebellar

(Option A ruled out)

Inferior cerebellar peduncle (decussates)

Excitatory terminals on Purkinje cells (glutamate)

Mossy fibres

Cerebro-ponto- cerebellar (Option B)

Middle cerebellar peduncle (decussates)

Excitatory terminals on granule cells (glutamate), which are excitatory to Purkinje cells

Spinocerebellar (Option C ruled out)
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle
  • Superior cerebellar peduncle

Vestibulo-cerebellar (Option D ruled out)

Inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: What is the significance of the second decussation of the ventral spinocerebellar tract within the cerebellum?

options.label: D
options.text: Causes all fibres to terminate bilaterally

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a severe infection of the face. Which of the following venous structures could allow the infection to spread to the cavernous sinus?
Which of the following conditions is associated with lesions at the level marked in the midbrain?

Which of the following is the correct match of brainstem components with the respective cranial nerve nuclei that originate from them? Column A Column B a. Midbrain 1. Trigeminal nerve b. Pons 2. Oculomotor nerve c. Medulla oblongata 3. Glossopharyngeal nerve d. Pontomedullary junction 4. Facial nerve
questions.explanation:
Components of brainstem

Cranial nerves nuclei

Midbrain

Oculomotor (III) and trochlear (IV)

Pons

Trigeminal (V)

Medulla oblongata

Glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), cranial accessory (XIcr) and hypoglossal (XII)

Pontomedullary junction

Abducens (VI), facial (VII) and vestibulocochlear (VIII)

questions.text: Match the following neural columns with their corresponding cranial nerve nuclei. 1. General Somatic Efferent (GSE) A) Nucleus ambiguus 2. Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) B) Edinger-Westphal nucleus 3. General Visceral Efferent (GVE) C) Oculomotor nucleus 4. Special Visceral Efferent (SVE) D) Nucleus of the solitary tract
questions.explanation:
1. General Somatic Efferent (GSE)

 

The GSE column controls muscles derived from somites, specifically the striated muscles.

C) Oculomotor nucleus

 

In the brainstem, it is represented by nuclei like the oculomotor nucleus, which innervates the extraocular muscles, facilitating eye movement.

2. Special Visceral Afferent (SVA)

 

The SVA column is responsible for processing special sensory information related to taste.

D) Nucleus of the solitary tract

 

In the brainstem, the nucleus of the solitary tract receives taste signals from the tongue, transmitted by cranial nerves like the facial and glossopharyngeal nerves.

3. General Visceral Efferent (GVE)

 

The GVE column regulates autonomic functions, particularly parasympathetic innervation.

B) Edinger-Westphal nucleus

 

The Edinger-Westphal nucleus in the midbrain is part of this system, controlling pupil constriction and lens accommodation.

4. Special Visceral Efferent (SVE)

 

The SVE column innervates muscles derived from the branchial arches, responsible for functions like swallowing and speech.

A) Nucleus ambiguus

 

The nucleus ambiguus provides motor innervation to muscles involved in these actions, via cranial nerves like the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves.

questions.text: A 62-year-old presents with sudden-onset left-sided weakness, primarily affecting the arm and face. On examination, he has difficulty with speech, displaying both expressive and receptive aphasia. He also shows left-sided facial drooping and an inability to move his left upper limb effectively. Sensation is relatively intact in his lower limb. Which artery is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:

  • ↳ Artery Affected Areas Involved Clinical Manifestations

  • ↳ Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (lower limb > upper limb)

  • ↳ Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) (Option C)
  • ↳ Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)
  • ↳ Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)
  • ↳ (Option C)
  • ↳ (Option C)
  • ↳ Lateral surface of the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes, basal ganglia, internal capsule

  • ↳ Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (face and upper limb > lower limb)
  • ↳ Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (face and upper limb > lower limb)

  • ↳ Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) (Option B)

Artery Affected

Areas Involved

Clinical Manifestations

Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)

(Option A)

Medial surface of the frontal and parietal lobes, corpus callosum
  • Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (lower limb > upper limb)
  • Urinary incontinence,
  • Personality changes (frontal lobe involvement),
  • Transcortical motor aphasia (dominant hemisphere)

Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)

(Option C)

Lateral surface of the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes, basal ganglia, internal capsule

Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA)

(Option B)

  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia,
  • Visual agnosia,
  • Thalamic pain syndrome,
  • Cortical blindness (if bilateral),
  • Memory deficits (if temporal lobe is involved)

questions.text: Identify the artery highlighted in blue in the following image.

Which of the following statements about prevertebral/paravertebral ganglia is/are true? Prevertebral ganglia are also known as collateral ganglia. Prevertebral ganglia are a part of the parasympathetic nervous system. Paravertebral ganglia supply the abdominal viscera. The celiac ganglion is a paravertebral ganglion.
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Prevertebral Ganglia

Paravertebral Ganglia

Alternate Names

Also known as collateral ganglia or preaortic ganglia. (Statement I)

Also known as sympathetic chain ganglia.

Sympathetic Pathway

Both are part of the sympathetic nervous system.

(Statement II ruled out)

Location

Anterior to the aorta, close to major arteries like the celiac, superior mesenteric, and inferior mesenteric arteries.

Adjacent to the vertebral column, forming sympathetic chains on either side of the spine.

Structure

Associated with the abdominal aorta and related to major arteries.

Forms a chain along the spine, with ganglia in the cervical, thoracic, lumbar, sacral, and coccygeal regions.

Function

Supplies abdominal and pelvic organs, controls visceral functions like peristalsis and secretion.

(Statement III ruled out)

Supplies the thoracic viscera, blood vessels, skin, sweat glands, and arrector pili muscles.

Preganglionic Fibers

Receive preganglionic fibers from the splanchnic nerves (e.g., greater, lesser, least splanchnic).

Receive preganglionic fibers from the spinal cord segments (T1-L2) via white rami communicantes.

Postganglionic Fibers

Postganglionic fibers form plexuses like the celiac and hypogastric plexus, supplying abdominal and pelvic organs.

Postganglionic fibers distributed via grey rami communicantes to spinal nerves and target skin, blood vessels, and thoracic viscera.

Notable Ganglia

Includes the celiac, superior mesenteric, inferior mesenteric, and aorticorenal ganglia.

(Statement IV ruled out)

Includes cervical, thoracic, lumbar, sacral ganglia, and ganglion impar.

questions.text: In the image below, which structure is labeled as the rostrum of the corpus callosum?

A 35 year old patient presents with rapid weight gain and persistent hunger despite adequate food intake. MRI reveals a lesion in the hypothalamus. Which of the following hypothalamic nuclei, when lesioned, is most likely to cause an uncontrolled appetite and extreme obesity?
questions.explanation:
Area/Nuclei

Function

Lesion

Anterior Hypothalamic Area & Preoptic Area (Option A)

Influences parasympathetic responses (e.g., lowers blood pressure, slows heart rate, heat regulation)

Can disrupt thermoregulation and lead to hyperthermia.

Posterior & Lateral Nuclei

Mediates sympathetic responses (e.g., increases blood pressure, accelerates heart rate, cold regulation).

May cause impaired sympathetic responses and issues with stress response.

Lateral Hypothalamus (Option C)

Acts as the hunger & thirst centre; stimulates food intake.

Leads to anorexia and significant weight loss.

Medial Hypothalamus- Ventromedial nucleus

Acts as the satiety centre; inhibits eating.

Causes uncontrolled appetite and extreme obesity.

Supraoptic & Paraventricular Nuclei

Secretes vasopressin and oxytocin; regulates water balance and reproductive functions.

Can disrupt water balance and lead to diabetes insipidus.

Suprachiasmatic Nucleus (Option D)

Regulates circadian rhythms and biological clocks.

Can disrupt sleep-wake cycles and lead to insomnia.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the anatomical relations of the internal capsule?

options.label: A
options.text: The anterior limb lies between the thalamus and the posterior part of the lentiform nucleus.

options.label: B
options.text: The genu is located posterior to the head of the caudate nucleus.

options.label: C
options.text: The medial boundary consists of the thalamus and the caudate nucleus.

options.label: D
options.text: The retro lentiform part is situated above the lentiform nucleus.

questions.correct_answer: C. The medial boundary consists of the thalamus and the caudate nucleus.

questions.text: Identify the correct option.

Match the Brodmann areas with their respective functions: Brodmann Area Function a) BA 1, 2, 3 1) Primary visual cortex b) BA 4 2) Primary motor cortex c) BA 17 3) Primary somatosensory cortex d) BA 44, 45 4) Language production (Broca’s area)
questions.explanation:
Brodmann’s numbers

Function

Location

BA 1, 2, 3
  • Primary Somatosensory Cortex
  • Processes tactile information from the body.

Postcentral gyrus.

BA 4
  • Primary Motor Cortex
  • Controls voluntary movements via corticospinal and cortico-nuclear tracts.

Precentral gyrus.

BA 8

  • Prefrontal Cortex
  • Involved in planning and decision-making.

The anterior part of the frontal lobe.

BA 17

  • Primary Visual Cortex (V1)
  • Processes visual information from the lateral geniculate nucleus.

Occipital lobe (calcarine sulcus, cuneus, and lingual gyrus).

BA 22
  • Language comprehension (Wernicke’s area)

Superior temporal gyrus

BA 41
  • Primary auditory cortex

Superior temporal gyrus

BA 42
  • Secondary auditory cortex

Adjacent to BA 41

BA 44 and 45
  • Broca’s area
  • Speech production.
  • BA 44 (Opercular part): Syntactic processing (grammar).
  • BA 45 (Triangular part): Semantic processing (meaning).
  • Left BA 44 is typically larger, reflecting language dominance.

Inferior frontal gyrus of the frontal lobe.

questions.text: A 68 year old male presents with sudden onset weakness in his right arm and face, along with difficulty speaking. MRI reveals an ischemic stroke. Which artery is most likely involved in this patient’s stroke based on his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Surface Type

Major Artery Supplied By

Lateral Surface

Middle cerebral artery (primary), anterior cerebral artery (superomedial border), posterior cerebral artery (occipital lobe, inferior temporal gyrus)

Medial & Inferior Surface

Anterior cerebral artery (largest area), middle cerebral artery (temporal pole, orbital surface), posterior cerebral artery (remaining areas)

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes the representation of body parts in the motor and sensory homunculi?

options.label: A
options.text: In the motor homunculus, finer motor control areas like arms and legs have larger cortical regions.

options.label: B
options.text: The sensory homunculus shows body parts with higher acuity, like fingertips, having smaller cortical areas.

options.label: C
options.text: Both homunculi are in the precentral gyrus and represent the same body parts.

options.label: D
options.text: The motor homunculus in the precentral gyrus has larger areas for fine motor parts like hands and face.

questions.correct_answer: D. The motor homunculus in the precentral gyrus has larger areas for fine motor parts like hands and face.

questions.text: Which sulcus is involved in separating the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe?
questions.explanation:
Lateral View

Medial View

  • Central Sulcus: Divides the frontal lobe (anterior) from the parietal lobe (posterior).
  • Lateral Sulcus: Distinguishes the temporal lobe from the frontal and parietal lobes.
  • Pre-central Gyrus: Located in front of the central sulcus; it contains the frontal motor cortex, which controls skeletal muscles.
  • Post-central Gyrus: Located behind the central sulcus; houses the parietal sensory cortex for general sensations (touch, pain, temperature, proprioception).
  • Insula: Found in the floor of the lateral sulcus.
  • Central Sulcus: Separates the frontal motor cortex (pre-central gyrus) from the parietal sensory cortex.
  • Paracentral Lobule: Controls the contralateral lower limb, pelvis, and perineum.
  • Calcarine Sulcus: Associated with the occipital visual cortex.
  • Limbic Lobe: Involved in emotions and memory.
  • Cingulate Gyrus: An arch-shaped convolution above the corpus callosum.

Layer

Function

I- Molecular layer

Receives nonspecific input signals from lower brain centers.
Control the excitability of stimulated areas.

II- External granular layer

Receives nonspecific input and sends axons to the opposite cortex through the corpus callosum.

III- External pyramidal layer

Sends axons to related cortical areas on the opposite side through the corpus callosum.

The outer band of Baillarger is a part of this layer of cerebral cortex, specifically located in the motor cortex and somatosensory cortex.

IV- Internal granular layer

The primary layer for receiving input sensory signals, which then spread to the surface and deeper layers.

V- Internal pyramidal layer

Sends large axons to distant nervous system parts like basal ganglia, brain stem, and spinal cord.
Controls signal transmission.

VI- Fusiform/ polymorphic layer

Sends axons to the thalamus.

Regulates excitability of incoming sensory signals.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy came with complaints of sudden onset weakness in his lower limbs. His parents mention a history of viral illness with fever and sore throat. On examination, the boy has flaccid paralysis of his legs with muscle wasting, absent deep tendon reflexes, and no sensory deficits. Which of the following structures is primarily affected in this condition, leading to muscle paralysis and wasting?

options.label: A
options.text: Posterior white columns of the spinal cord

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior grey columns of the spinal cord

questions.correct_answer: B. Anterior grey columns of the spinal cord

questions.text: Which arteries supply the posterior region of the superior medulla and pons respectively?

options.label: A
options.text: Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery and Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior Spinal Artery and Posterior Spinal Artery

options.label: D
options.text: Superior Cerebellar Artery and Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery and Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

questions.text: The nucleus of the solitary tract receives ______ sensations from the carotid body and carotid sinus primarily through _____ nerve.
questions.correct_answer: C. General Visceral Afferent; Glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.text: Which cranial nerve motor fibres are responsible for innervating skeletal muscles that develop from somites?
questions.explanation:
Motor Neural Columns
 

GSE (General Somatic Efferent)

(Option A)

GVE (General Visceral Efferent)

(Option C ruled out)

SVE (Special Visceral Efferent )

(Option B ruled out)

Innervation

Motor innervation to skeletal muscles that develop from somites.

Autonomic (involuntary) innervation to smooth muscles and glands.

Innervate muscles that are derived from pharyngeal arches, not somites.

Function

Voluntary movements such as eye and tongue movements.

Functions such as pupil constriction, salivation, digestion, and heart rate regulation.

Functions like facial expression, mastication, and swallowing.

Nerves
  • Oculomotor (III)
  • Trochlear (IV)
  • Abducens (VI)
  • Hypoglossal (XII)
  • Oculomotor (III)
  • Facial (VII)
  • Glossopharyngeal (IX)
  • Vagus (X)
  • Facial (VII)
  • Trigeminal (V)
  • Accessory spinal nerve (XI)

questions.text: Which association fibre connects Wernicke's area with Broca's area
questions.explanation:
Arcuate fasciculus

Uncinate fasciculus

(Option A ruled out)

Inferior and Superior longitudinal fasciculus

(Option B & D ruled out)
  • It is seen on the left side of the cerebrum.
  • In 95% of people, the language area is on the left dominant hemisphere.
  • Wernicke's sensory speech area in the temporal lobe is connected with Broca's motor speech area in the inferior frontal gyrus by arcuate fasciculus.
  • It does not cross the midline.
  • Connecting the temporal lobe with the frontal lobe.
  • It does not cross the midline.
  • Superior longitudinal fasciculus: Connects the anterior part of the frontal lobe to the occipital and temporal lobes.
  • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus: Connects the occipital lobe to the temporal lobe.
  • They do not cross the midline.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cross the midline?
questions.explanation:
Commissural fibres

Projection

They connect one hemisphere to the opposite side, linking corresponding (homotopic) or different (heterotopic) areas. 

  • Corpus Callosum: The largest commissural structure connecting the two cerebral hemispheres, located at the bottom of the longitudinal fissure. (Option A ruled out)
  • Anterior Commissure: A smaller bundle of nerve fibres crossing the midline at the lamina terminalis.(Option B ruled out)
  • Fornix: Composed of myelinated fibres, it connects the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies in the hypothalamus. It connects the hippocampal formations of the 2 sides. (Option C ruled out)

Projection fibres connect the cerebral cortex with subcortical structures, including the brainstem and spinal cord, and include both descending (corticofugal) and ascending (corticopetal) fibres.

These fibres converge in the corona radiata, pass through the internal capsule, and are flanked by the caudate nucleus and thalamus medially, and the lentiform nucleus laterally.

questions.text: Match the following boundary of the 4th ventricle with its component. 1. Lateral wall a) Superior medullary velum 2. Posterior wall b) Superior medulla 3. Rhomboid fossa c) Superior cerebellar peduncle
questions.explanation:
Boundaries of 4th Ventricle

Description

Lateral Wall
  • Inferolaterally- Inferior cerebellar peduncle, and gracile and cuneate tubercles
  • Superolaterally- Superior cerebellar peduncle

Roof (Posterior Wall)
  • Superior Part:
    • Medial borders of the two superior cerebellar peduncles.
    • Superior medullary velum (a sheet of white matter).
  • Inferior Part:
    • Inferior medullary velum (ventricular ependyma and pia mater)
    • Median aperture (foramen of Magendie) in the midline.
  • Lateral Recesses:
    • Extend laterally around the medulla.
    • Open anteriorly as the foramina of Luschka (lateral openings of the fourth ventricle).

Rhomboid Fossa (Floor)
  • The posterior surface of the pons
  • The upper part of the medulla

questions.text: Which of the given options are correctly matched based on the image given?

A 7-year-old girl presents with severe headaches, vomiting, and papilloedema. Imaging reveals obstructive hydrocephalus due to a tumour blocking the exit of cerebrospinal fluid from the fourth ventricle. Which of the following structures is most likely blocked?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Foramen of Magendie

(Median aperture)

Foramina of Luschka

(Lateral aperture)

Location

Caudal to the cerebellar nodule

At the ends of the lateral recesses of the 4th ventricle.

Function

Main communication between ventricles and subarachnoid space

Allow communication between the fourth ventricle and the subarachnoid space.

Associated Pathology

Obstruction leads to hydrocephalus.

 

A blockage here would prevent CSF from exiting medially into the subarachnoid space.

Obstruction leads to hydrocephalus.

 

A blockage here prevents CSF from exiting laterally from the fourth ventricle.

Symptoms of Obstruction

Headache, vomiting, papilloedema

Headache, vomiting, papilloedema
